name: wind turbine construction, 2.3MW, precast concrete tower, onshore | wind turbine, 2.3MW, onshore | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/10545/documentation

This dataset represents the construction of a wind turbine with a capacity of 2.3MW for onshore use. The term "wind turbine" inludes moving parts such as nacelle, rotor, rotor blades, transition piece as well as fixed parts such as the tower and the foundation.This turbine is characterized by the precast concrete tower and the annular generator (no gearbox in the nacelle).  ;This global is a copy of the regional dataset for Quebec, as data were collecter for this region.;;The LCI model is based on a LCA study of ENERCON E-82 E2 2.3MW with 107 meter precast concrete turbines. Some data (construction and dismantling operations) that were not included in the main source are adapted from the dataset "wind turbine construction, 2MW, onshore, GLO".Electronic parts are also adapted as the reference study does not differentiate between the electric parts of the turbine and the substation.;Parts of the wind turbine are the following: ;Nacelle: casing, rotor hub, axle pins, blade adapter and the main carrier;Annular generator: rotor ansd stator;Blades;Tower (precast concrete).;Foundation (steel and concrete)

From the transformation of pasture land to industrial site, and from the reception and treatment of building materials and turbine parts.

This activity ends with the decommissioning of the wind turbine and the treatment of the resulting materials in the end of the lifetime.

This dataset includes 
 - all materials for the construction of the wind turbine and their treatment, but not the energy for their assembling
 - land transformation and use
 - energy needed for erection and dismantling of the wind turbine.

This dataset doesn't include 
 - the connection to the grid, which is modeled in a separate dataset.
 - the operation and maintenance of the fully finished wind power plant. It is assumed that all parts will hold for the lifetime of 20 years and don't have to be replaced. 
 - auxiliary materials such as packaging materials or vacuum fleece.  
 - any losses of materials (waste) during the processing of the different wind turbine parts.
 - neither the energy use for assembly of the different wind turbine parts nor their transportation from manufacture to the construction site.
category: C:Manufacturing/28:Manufacture of machinery and equipment n.e.c./281:Manufacture of general-purpose machinery/2811:Manufacture of engines and turbines, except aircraft, vehicle and cycle eng

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Turbines present in 2008 in Quebec wind power park. Lifespan of 20 years
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The Enercon E82-2.3 MW turbine is chosen as reference technology.;Characteristics: ; - Capacity: 2300 kW ;- Diameter of the rotor: 82 m; - Number of rotor blades: 3; - rotor blade weight: 7300 kg; - nacelle weight: 132000 kg; ; - tower type: modular concrete and steel towerr;- tower weight: 727000 kg; - material of the tower: Steel and concrete; - foundation weight: 746000; - Lifetime: 20 years;;Source: data collection and Enercon (http://www.enercon.de/p/downloads/EN_Productoverview_0710.pdf) ;;Further characteristics:;;Operational data;Rated power: 2,300 kW;Cut-in wind speed: 2 m/s;Rated wind speed: 16 m/s;Cut-out wind speed: 28 - 34 m/s;Wind class: IEC/NVN IIA;;Rotor;Rotor diameter: 82 m;Swept area: 5,281 m2;Nominal revolutions: 16.7 rpm;Operational interval: 6-18 rpm;Generator: ENERCON direct-drive annular ;generator;Main bearing: Double-row tapered / cylindrical roller bearingsBrake systems: (1)3 independent pitch control systems with emergency power supply; (2) Rotor brake; (3)Rotor lock;;Source: Enercon, 2010, ENERCON Wind energy converters
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Some of the data that were not detailed in the main document are extrapolated (construction, dismantling operations) from the dataset "wind turbine construction, 2MW, onshore, GLO". Uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.

flow.name: wind turbine, 2.3MW, onshore
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/28:Manufacture of machinery and equipment n.e.c./281:Manufacture of general-purpose machinery/2811:Manufacture of engines and turbines, except aircraft, vehicle and cycle eng

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Concrete used for foundation and in tower structure.

Estimated values based on % of total weight per component and material of the turbine published by the Princeton Energy Resources International, LLC

flow.category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2395:Manufacture of articles of concrete, cement and plaster

defaultProvider.name: market for concrete, normal strength | concrete, normal strength | Cutoff, U
defaultProvider.category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2395:Manufacture of articles of concrete, cement and plaster

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The glass fibre reinforced plastic of the rotor is disposed of as 50% glass and 50% plastic. When using PrePreg in the manufacturing process, up to 10% of the PrePreg turns into waste due to cutoffs directly. A large percentage of this waste is sent to recycling as it is directly used in the production of e.g. high-strength construction panels. The remaining glass fibre reinforced plastic amount will turn into waste/by-product after 20 years.

Today, it is not possible to recycle the turbine blades. When the turbine’s lifetime expires, the blades will
be dismantled into smaller pieces, which are deposited at controlled waste deposits.[Elsam. 2004b. Life Cycle Assessment of turbines PSO 1999. Elsam Engineering A/S, Fredericia, Denmark]

exchanges.description:
Estimated value. Value taken from the 2MW wind turbine construction
Literature value/estimation. Generally a combination of tarred roads and dirt roads need to be built to provide access to the power plant turbines, which are often located in remote locations. It has been estimated that 10 km of tarred road is needed for a power plant with 25 wind turbines. 

No maintenance is assumed.

exchanges.description:
Literature value. Used for the rotor blades. The main materials used in the rotor blades are glass  fibres and epoxy resin.
Split between materials is based on prepeg used in the 2MW dataset.
Prepreg is used as material for the blades in this dataset. It was not possible to get information on the exact composition of Prepreg. From the supplier’s PrePreg safety data sheets it is assumed that Prepreg consists of approx 40% epoxy and 60% glass fibre. Total Prepreg mass is 21507 kg. When using PrePreg in the manufacturing process, up to 10% of the PrePreg turns into waste due to cutoffs.

Extrapolated value from 2MW GLO dataset
Literature value / calculation: Additional to energy requirements for material processing, a factor of 0.5 kWh/kg material (except of concrete for the foundation) after is included.Total wind turbine weight is about 2243554 kg (see Technology comment for details). This should also cover the energy required for mounting and removal of the turbine.

Literature value / calculation: Additional to energy requirements for material processing, a factor of 0.5 kWh/kg material (except of concrete for the foundation) after is included.Total wind turbine weight is about 2243554 kg (see Technology comment for details). This should also cover the energy required for mounting and removal of the turbine.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Proxy for the treatment of the epoxy resin (polyepoxide, formed from reaction of an epoxide resin with polyamine hardener). When using PrePreg in the manufacturing process, up to 10% of the PrePreg turns into waste due to cutoffs directly. The remaining amount will turn into waste/by-product after 20 years.

exchanges.description:
Estimated value based on 2MW GLO dataset. 

The glass fibre reinforced plastic of the rotor is disposed of as 50% glass and 50% plastic. When using PrePreg in the manufacturing process, up to 10% of the PrePreg turns into waste due to cutoffs directly. The remaining amount will turn into waste/by-product after 20 years.

Today, it is not possible to recycle the turbine blades. When the turbine’s lifetime expires, the blades will
be dismantled into smaller pieces, which are deposited at controlled waste deposits.[Elsam. 2004b. Life Cycle Assessment of turbines PSO 1999. Elsam Engineering A/S, Fredericia, Denmark]

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated value. Aluminium used in rotor blades and nacelle.
The shares of cast alloy and wrought alloy aluminium in the cancelled ecoinvent v2 "aluminium production mix" dataset amounted to 32% (cast alloy) and 68% (wrought alloy) respectively. These shares have been overtaken to distribute the original amount of 1299 kg aluminium.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The glass fibre reinforced plastic of the rotor is disposed of as 50% glass and 50% plastic. When using PrePreg in the manufacturing process, up to 10% of the PrePreg turns into waste due to cutoffs directly. A large percentage of this waste is sent to recycling as it is directly used in the production of e.g. high-strength construction panels. The remaining glass fibre reinforced plastic amount will turn into waste/by-product after 20 years.

Today, it is not possible to recycle the turbine blades. When the turbine’s lifetime expires, the blades will
be dismantled into smaller pieces, which are deposited at controlled waste deposits.[Elsam. 2004b. Life Cycle Assessment of turbines PSO 1999. Elsam Engineering A/S, Fredericia, Denmark]

flow.name: Transformation, to industrial area
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/land

exchanges.description:
Literature value. Used for the rotor blades. The main materials used in the rotor blades are glass  fibres and epoxy resin.
Split between materials is based on prepeg used in the 2MW dataset.
Prepreg is used as material for the blades in this dataset. It was not possible to get information on the exact composition of Prepreg. From the supplier’s PrePreg safety data sheets it is assumed that Prepreg consists of approx 40% epoxy and 60% glass fibre. Total Prepreg mass is 21507 kg. When using PrePreg in the manufacturing process, up to 10% of the PrePreg turns into waste due to cutoffs.

flow.category: C:Manufacturing/22:Manufacture of rubber and plastics products/222:Manufacture of plastics products/2220:Manufacture of plastics products

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The glass fibre reinforced plastic of the rotor is disposed of as 50% glass and 50% plastic. When using PrePreg in the manufacturing process, up to 10% of the PrePreg turns into waste due to cutoffs directly. A large percentage of this waste is sent to recycling as it is directly used in the production of e.g. high-strength construction panels. The remaining glass fibre reinforced plastic amount will turn into waste/by-product after 20 years.

Today, it is not possible to recycle the turbine blades. When the turbine’s lifetime expires, the blades will
be dismantled into smaller pieces, which are deposited at controlled waste deposits.[Elsam. 2004b. Life Cycle Assessment of turbines PSO 1999. Elsam Engineering A/S, Fredericia, Denmark]
